igual."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:00.000", "14:01.000", ["Sí."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:01.000", "14:06.000", ["Esa mezcla se revuelve bien y luego se le echa una gotica de alcohol para darle aroma"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:06.000", "14:09.000", ["y unas hojitas de perejil para darle sustancia."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:09.000", "14:11.000", ["De modo que agua salada, salfumán y creolina."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:11.000", "14:12.000", ["Sí."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:12.000", "14:14.000", ["Eso debe acabar con los motores, ¿verdad?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:14.000", "14:16.000", ["¿Cómo no va a acabar, doctor?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:16.000", "14:19.000", ["Y nosotros le echamos 40 galones al vehículo."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:19.000", "14:20.000", ["Sí, pero es usted."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:20.000", "14:23.000", ["Como que es para agarrar la guagua y darle con ella en la cabeza."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:23.000", "14:24.000", ["No, no, no."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:24.000", "14:25.000", ["Mira cómo es la cosa."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:25.000", "14:26.000", ["De eso nada, de eso nada."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:26.000", "14:27.000", ["Dele con otra cosa."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:27.000", "14:29.000", ["Pero con la guagua no, porque me puede usted estropear la carrocería."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:29.000", "14:33.000", ["Bueno, tres patines, ¿y usted vende esa sambumbia como si fuera gasolina?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:33.000", "14:35.000", ["Sí, pero la vende cinco kilos, no más galón."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:35.000", "14:36.000", ["Uy, es que es un regalo, chico."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:36.000", "14:37.000", ["¿Un regalo de qué, chico?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:37.000", "14:39.000", ["Con eso no hay guagua que camine."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:39.000", "14:40.000", ["¿Cómo va a ser regalo?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:40.000", "14:41.000", ["Es que tengo yo que ver con eso, señora."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:41.000", "14:43.000", ["¿Cómo no va a tener que ver tres patines?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:43.000", "14:46.000", ["¿Usted no la vende como si sirviera para caminar?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:46.000", "14:47.000", ["No, chico, todo lo contrario."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:47.000", "14:49.000", ["¿Cómo todo lo contrario?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:49.000", "14:52.000", ["El letrero no dice gasolina especial para guaguas."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:52.000", "14:53.000", ["Sí, chico."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:53.000", "14:56.000", ["¿Y eso que usted vende es gasolina para guaguas?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:56.000", "14:57.000", ["Para guaguas, sí, señor."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:57.000", "15:00.000", ["Porque guagua a la que se le echa esa gasolina."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:00.000", "15:03.000", ["Guagua que se para y ya no se mueve más, chico."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:03.000", "15:05.000", ["¿Qué dice usted? No se mueve más nunca."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:05.000", "15:06.000", ["Claro que no, chico."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:06.000", "15:09.000", ["Si se moviera sería gasolina mueve guagua."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:09.000", "15:11.000", ["Y la que yo vendo es para guagua."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:11.000", "15:12.000", ["Gasolina para guagua."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:12.000", "15:15.000", ["Porque la, oye, la hace parar definitivamente."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:15.000", "15:17.000", ["Y ya no vuelve a caminar más."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:17.000", "15:19.000", ["Pero eso es una estafa, tres patines."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:19.000", "15:20.000", ["No, chico, eso no es una estafa."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:20.000", "15:21.000", ["¿Cómo que no?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:21.000", "15:26.000", ["No, es una mezcla, mira, hijo, de agua salada, sal fumada y creolina."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:26.000", "15:29.000", ["Entonces tú haces así, tú tienes máquina."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:29.000", "15:30.000", ["Sí."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:30.000", "15:33.000", ["¿Quieres echarle diez galoncitos para que tú veas cómo es la cosa?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:33.000", "15:34.000", ["Yo escriba ahí, secretario."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:34.000", "15:36.000", ["¡Venga la sentencia!"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:36.000", "15:39.000", ["Habría que ser muy bobo, muy tonto y muy no sé qué,"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:39.000", "15:42.000", ["para no ver que es un robo eso que está haciendo usted."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:42.000", "15:44.000", ["Pague, pues, sin discusiones los daños,"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:44.000", "15:48.000", ["porque si no le haré beber diez galones de esa mezcla que inventó."])]
[ Info: Any[Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:WEBVTT, "", "", "", String[]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "00:00.000", "00:11.000", ["La Tremenda Corte"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "00:11.000", "00:22.000", ["Con Leopoldo Fernández, Aníbal de Mar, Mimical, Adolfo Otero y Julito Díaz, escribe Castor Bisco, producción y dirección de Baco Lara."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "00:23.000", "00:33.000", ["Audiencia pública, el tremendo juez de la Tremenda Corte va a resolver un tremendo caso."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "00:33.000", "00:35.000", ["Buenas noches, secretario."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "00:35.000", "00:38.000", ["Buenas noches, señor juez. ¿Cómo se siente hoy de salud?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "00:38.000", "00:39.000", ["Muy mal, muy mal."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "00:39.000", "00:40.000", ["¿Qué le pasa?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "00:40.000", "00:46.000", ["Que la humedad esta que ha traído la perturbación ciclónica me tiene con el reuma echando candela."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "00:46.000", "00:48.000", ["Vaya por Dios, pobrecita ella."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "00:48.000", "00:50.000", ["¿Cómo? ¿A quién le ha dicho usted ella?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "00:50.000", "00:53.000", ["No, a la perturbación ciclónica, doctor. No se llama ella."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "00:53.000", "00:56.000", ["Ah, vamos, yo creía. Pero pobrecita, ¿por qué?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "00:56.000", "01:02.000", ["Porque le está usted echando la culpa de su reuma y eso es una injusticia. Porque usted ya tenía reuma antes de que viniera esa perturbación."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:02.000", "01:07.000", ["Sí, pero no lo tenía echando candela. Lo tenía echando humo, nada más."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:07.000", "01:09.000", ["¿Y dónde hay humo? No tiene que haber candela."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:09.000", "01:13.000", ["No, señor, porque en la cueva del humo hay humo y sin embargo no hay candela ninguna."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:13.000", "01:16.000", ["Ah, ¿verdad? Entonces tiene usted razón, doctor. ¿Cuánto me pongo de humo?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:16.000", "01:17.000", ["No, nada, nada."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:17.000", "01:18.000", ["Sí, me decía algo."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:18.000", "01:20.000", ["Que vengo benevolente hoy."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:20.000", "01:22.000", ["Límites a decirme qué caso tenemos para hoy."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:22.000", "01:27.000", ["Con mucho gusto, doctor. Lo que tenemos hoy es un caso de daños hiperjuicios."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:27.000", "01:29.000", ["¿Dónde fueron causados esos daños?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:29.000", "01:30.000", ["En una finca."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:30.000", "01:32.000", ["Pues llámelo complicado en ese finquisidio."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:32.000", "01:34.000", ["Enseguida, señor juez."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:34.000", "01:36.000", ["Luz María Nananina."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:36.000", "01:38.000", ["Aquí como todos los días."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:38.000", "01:41.000", ["Rudecindo Caldeiro y Escobiña."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:41.000", "01:43.000", ["¡Gente!"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:43.000", "01:46.000", ["José Candelario Trespatines."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:46.000", "01:48.000", ["¡A la reja!"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:50.000", "01:52.000", ["Vamos a ver quién acusa aquí hoy."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:52.000", "01:53.000", ["Yo, señor juez."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:53.000", "01:57.000", ["Oye, eso qué manera de vociferar."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:57.000", "01:58.000", ["¿Por qué? ¿Yo he dicho algo mal dicho?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "01:58.000", "02:02.000", ["Sí, señora. Ha demostrado usted tener muy poca educación."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:02.000", "02:04.000", ["Porque al señor juez no se le contesta, yo."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:04.000", "02:06.000", ["¿Ay, qué se le contesta entonces?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:06.000", "02:08.000", ["Tiene que decirle a usted servidera."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:08.000", "02:13.000", ["Cuando el señor juez le pregunte quién acusa, usted debe contestar, una servidera."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:13.000", "02:16.000", ["Ay, esas lesiones de cortesía, Trespatines."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:16.000", "02:17.000", ["¿De dónde le ha sacado usted?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:17.000", "02:19.000", ["Bueno, chico, no es así como se debe contestar."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:19.000", "02:22.000", ["Sí, pero no se dice servidera, sino servidora."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:22.000", "02:24.000", ["¿Servidora? ¿De qué verbo es eso?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:24.000", "02:25.000", ["Del verbo servir."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:25.000", "02:29.000", ["Ah, no, yo digo servidera, del verbo servilleta, chico."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:29.000", "02:31.000", ["¿Y servilleta es un verbo, Trespatines?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:31.000", "02:32.000", ["Como no, chico."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:32.000", "02:35.000", ["La conjugación del verbo servir, servidera, chico."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:35.000", "02:38.000", ["Yo servilleta, tu cuchara, el otro plato, tenedor."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:38.000", "02:39.000", ["Todo eso del mismo verbo, chico."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:39.000", "02:40.000", ["¿De qué verbo?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:40.000", "02:41.000", ["Del verbo comer, hijo."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:41.000", "02:45.000", ["Mire, Trespatines, no me des más lesiones aquí y acláreme una cosa."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:45.000", "02:49.000", ["¿Usted no me dijo anoche que a Nananina se le había llevado el ciclón?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:49.000", "02:53.000", ["Sí, pero parece que al ciclón le pasó lo mismo que a mí, ¿no?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:53.000", "02:57.000", ["Que no la pudo resistir y tuvo que largarla, oye, medio de ola."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "02:57.000", "03:01.000", ["Un momento, un momento, vamos a aclarar eso."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:01.000", "03:02.000", ["No, no, eso te aclaro."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:02.000", "03:08.000", ["No, hasta el gato sabe que la que no lo pudo resistir a usted y lo largó de ola fui yo."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:08.000", "03:09.000", ["¿Qué cosa?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:09.000", "03:11.000", ["Yo fui que lo largué a usted."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:11.000", "03:12.000", ["Eso lo sabe hasta el gato."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:12.000", "03:13.000", ["Sí, señor."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:13.000", "03:14.000", ["¿Y quién se lo dijo al gato?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:14.000", "03:18.000", ["Te lo dije yo y por eso el gato se quedó conmigo en lugar de irse con usted."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:18.000", "03:21.000", ["Se quedó con usted porque el gato come pitrafa conmigo."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:21.000", "03:23.000", ["Ya, ya."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:23.000", "03:24.000", ["Vamos."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:24.000", "03:25.000", ["Ya."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:25.000", "03:29.000", ["El caso es que usted no se la llevó a ningún ciclón, ¿verdad, Nananina?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:29.000", "03:30.000", ["No, señor."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:30.000", "03:34.000", ["Y eso de que Trespatines se ponga a decir aquí cosas de mí los días que yo no vengo"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:34.000", "03:38.000", ["se va a terminar porque cuando no pueda venir yo voy a vendar aquí que venga mi hermano"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:38.000", "03:39.000", ["Zenón para que usted vea."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:39.000", "03:40.000", ["¿Quién?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:40.000", "03:41.000", ["A Zenón, mi hermano, chico."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:41.000", "03:42.000", ["¿Y a mí qué?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:42.000", "03:46.000", ["Dígale a su hermano Zenón que venga mañana mismo si quiere que le voy a echar un ojo."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:46.000", "03:47.000", ["¿Qué cosa?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:47.000", "03:49.000", ["Le digo eso yo a mi hermano Zenón."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:49.000", "03:50.000", ["Sí, señora."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:50.000", "03:53.000", ["Zenón no es más chiquito el que tiene nueve años."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:53.000", "03:54.000", ["No, señor."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:54.000", "03:58.000", ["Zenón es el mayor, el que tiene 35 años, grande, gordo."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "03:58.000", "04:00.000", ["Bueno, pues no le diga nada."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:00.000", "04:01.000", ["¿Qué pasó?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:01.000", "04:02.000", ["¿Qué pasó, Trespatines?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:02.000", "04:04.000", ["¿Le cogió usted miedo a Zenón?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:04.000", "04:05.000", ["Sí, chico, le cogí miedo."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:05.000", "04:06.000", ["¿Qué?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:06.000", "04:07.000", ["¿Te importa algo?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:07.000", "04:09.000", ["¿Te importa por contestarle al juez de esa manera?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:09.000", "04:11.000", ["Dígame usted, nana Nina, ¿quién acusa a usted?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:11.000", "04:14.000", ["Yo a los dos, señor juez, a Rudecinto y a Trespatines."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:14.000", "04:16.000", ["Bueno, oígame, nena Nina."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:16.000", "04:17.000", ["Nena no, nana."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:17.000", "04:24.000", ["Nani Nina, nani Nina, pero usted comete una injusticia incalificable al acosarme a mí"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:24.000", "04:27.000", ["porque yo he sido una víctima de Trespatines."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:27.000", "04:28.000", ["¿Ah, sí?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:28.000", "04:30.000", ["¿Usted por qué le hizo caso a Trespatines?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:30.000", "04:32.000", ["Bueno, en eso tiene usted razón, ¿no?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:32.000", "04:34.000", ["Ponme un peso de multa ahí, secretario."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:34.000", "04:35.000", ["No, señor, ¿qué va?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:35.000", "04:37.000", ["Eso no se arregla con un peso de multa."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:37.000", "04:41.000", ["A mí hay que pagarme una indemnización de 5.500 pesos, por lo menos."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:41.000", "04:43.000", ["¿5.500 pesos?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:43.000", "04:46.000", ["Oiga, eso es más que 8.80, ¿verdad?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:46.000", "04:47.000", ["Ya lo creo que es más que 8.80."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:47.000", "04:50.000", ["Bueno, pues no le haga caso a esa mujer, chico, que está loca, chico."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:50.000", "04:52.000", ["No, no, nada de loca, que yo estoy muy cuerda."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:52.000", "04:54.000", ["¿Cuerda de dónde?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:54.000", "04:59.000", ["¿Usted cree que te cuerda a una mujer que tiene matas sembradas en la azotea de su casa?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "04:59.000", "05:00.000", ["¿Por qué no a Trespatines?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:00.000", "05:04.000", ["En los Estados Unidos hay muchos edificios que tienen jardines en las azoteas."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:04.000", "05:07.000", ["Sí, pero es morrer el remolache de esos, chicos."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:07.000", "05:11.000", ["Pero lo que siembran esos jardines son con flores, no eso."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:11.000", "05:13.000", ["¿Y tú sabes lo que sembró la doña esta?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:13.000", "05:14.000", ["¿Qué sembró?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:14.000", "05:15.000", ["Guayabos, chicos, matas de guayabos."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:15.000", "05:18.000", ["No me digas, nananina, usted sembró guayabos en la azotea de tu casa."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:18.000", "05:22.000", ["Sí, señor, pues, pero no son guayabos grandes, son unos guayabitos pequeños."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:22.000", "05:24.000", ["¿Qué hubo? ¿Se convence de que está loca?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:24.000", "05:25.000", ["¿Por qué Trespatines?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:25.000", "05:26.000", ["¿Por qué va a ser, chico?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:26.000", "05:29.000", ["¿No acaba de confesar ella misma que tiene guayabitos en la azotea, chico?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:29.000", "05:32.000", ["¿Cómo, cómo? Nananina tiene guayabitos en la azotea."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:32.000", "05:35.000", ["Claro que sí, por eso el gato se quedó con ella."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:35.000", "05:36.000", ["No es verdad."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:36.000", "05:40.000", ["El gato se quedó conmigo porque yo le expliqué el problema entre usted y yo."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:40.000", "05:43.000", ["Y él se dio cuenta de que la razón estaba de mi parte."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "05:43.000", "05:46.000", ["Sí, pero Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "11:38.080", "11:39.080", ["Sí."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "11:39.080", "11:40.080", ["Está bien."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "11:40.080", "11:41.080", ["Está consciente, chico."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "11:41.080", "11:42.080", ["Siga, nananina."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "11:42.080", "11:43.080", ["¿Qué pasó con esa finca?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "11:43.160", "11:47.920", ["Es nada que yo se la di a cuidar a Rudezindo, pero Rudezindo se llevó de ayudante a tres"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "11:47.920", "11:52.120", ["patines y en dos meses nada más que estuvieron en la finca me acabaron con ella."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "11:52.120", "11:53.120", ["No, no."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "11:53.120", "11:55.040", ["Oiga, tampoco así, nananina."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "11:55.040", "11:59.480", ["No diga que la acabamos con ella porque la finca está en el mismo sitio en que estaba."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "11:59.480", "12:02.960", ["Sí, pero me acabaron con toda la siembra de frijoles que yo tenía en ella."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:02.960", "12:03.960", ["Un momento, nananina."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:03.960", "12:06.240", ["¿No habrá sido el ciclón el que acabó con esa siembra?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:06.240", "12:07.240", ["No, doctor."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:07.240", "12:08.240", ["De eso nada."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:08.240", "12:09.240", ["¡Nada!"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:09.240", "12:12.760", ["En una finca que esté cuidando yo no hay ciclón que me entre."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:13.440", "12:14.440", ["¿Cómo que no hay ciclón que le entre?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:14.440", "12:15.440", ["No, señor."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:15.440", "12:19.040", ["Si hace demanda entrar nada más, le meto una galleta que es lo del barato."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:19.040", "12:20.040", ["¿Al ciclón?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:20.040", "12:21.040", ["Sí, señor, al ciclón."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:21.040", "12:22.600", ["¿Y cómo le mete usted una galleta al ciclón?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:22.600", "12:27.000", ["Pues lo espera y cuando venga, mire, doctor, oiga, no me haga perder el tiempo."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:27.000", "12:28.560", ["¿Cómo que no le haga perder el tiempo?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:28.560", "12:29.560", ["No, señor."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:29.560", "12:34.120", ["Esos son asuntos de carácter meteorológico que no los entendemos más que yo y el comandante"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:34.120", "12:35.120", ["Milías."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:35.120", "12:36.120", ["Bueno, bueno."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:36.120", "12:37.760", ["¿Fueron ustedes entonces quienes acabaron con esa siembra?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:37.760", "12:39.760", ["Hombre, yo creo que sí, sí, señor."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:39.760", "12:42.120", ["¿Nananina, fueron ellos los que acabaron con las siembras estas?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:42.480", "12:43.480", ["¿Se veía que sí?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:43.480", "12:44.480", ["Sí, señor."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:44.480", "12:49.080", ["Figures usted, señor juez, que rudeciendo me dijo que sabía mucho de eso y no sabía"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:49.080", "12:50.080", ["ni una palabra."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:50.080", "12:54.720", ["Un momento, señora, yo le he dicho a usted que tenía la medalla del mérito agrícola"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:54.720", "12:55.720", ["y eso es verdad."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:55.720", "12:58.360", ["No me diga, usted tiene la medalla del mérito agrícola."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "12:58.360", "13:03.000", ["Sí, señor, la tengo empeñada, pero la tengo, porque yo soy un agricultor de primera."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:03.000", "13:07.600", ["No lo va a tener, la tiene grandísima, la medalla del médico agrícola, que es una"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:07.600", "13:11.480", ["rueda de ñame grandísima con dos bonitos pintados atravesados."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:11.840", "13:14.520", ["No, de eso nada, de eso nada."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:14.520", "13:18.800", ["El ñame y los buñatos, eso, el melón y el tronco de yuca honoris causa, ese que ustedes"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:18.800", "13:23.640", ["me quieren dosarlos, será usted, que fue quien acabó con las siembras de frijoles."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:23.640", "13:24.640", ["Ah, fue Tres Patines."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:24.640", "13:30.800", ["Sí, señor juez, porque yo quería regar esos frijoles con agua, pero Tres Patines me aguantó"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:30.800", "13:32.560", ["y me dijo que no lo hiciera."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:32.560", "13:35.320", ["Claro que no, chico, ¿quién ha visto eso?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:35.320", "13:39.640", ["Es de primer año, rudeciendo, porque los frijoles no se rieguen con agua."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:39.640", "13:41.040", ["¿Con qué se rieguen entonces?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:41.600", "13:42.600", ["Según el color."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:42.600", "13:43.600", ["¿Cómo según el color?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:43.600", "13:49.160", ["Sí, señor, claro, los frijoles blancos hay que regarlos con cal y los frijoles negros"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:49.160", "13:50.600", ["con tinta rápida, chico."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:50.600", "13:52.680", ["No me digas, ¿y los frijoles colorados?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:52.680", "13:55.520", ["Los frijoles colorados, eso se riega con mercuro crónico, chico."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:55.520", "13:58.840", ["Bueno, ¿y qué le pasó a la siembra de frijoles?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "13:58.840", "14:02.960", ["Que se secaron, señor juez, porque estos tipos no saben ni regar siquiera."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:02.960", "14:07.480", ["Que no, explíquenles a juez cómo se riega la mata de coco, rudeciendo."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:07.520", "14:11.720", ["Bueno, doctor, yo verduremente no sé si eso estará correcto, ¿no?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:11.720", "14:15.440", ["Pero Tres Patines dice que las matas de coco hay que regarlas con guarapo."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:15.440", "14:16.720", ["¿Y eso para qué?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:16.720", "14:19.040", ["Para que el agua de coco salga ya con azúcar."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:19.040", "14:20.040", ["Claro que sí, chico."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:20.040", "14:24.160", ["Y a propósito, ¿no sería bueno regar con guarapo los boñatos también, chico?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:24.160", "14:25.160", ["¿Para qué?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:25.160", "14:27.160", ["Hombre, para ver si sale boñatí ya del tiro."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:27.160", "14:29.640", ["Bueno, bueno, yo creo que no."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:29.640", "14:33.360", ["Para que salga boñatí yo habría que machacar primero las semillas."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:33.360", "14:34.920", ["Sí, se puede probar, chico."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:34.920", "14:38.120", ["Bueno, se puede probar, es para mi finca, no van a probar otra vez."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:38.120", "14:39.560", ["Ahí no entran más ustedes."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:39.560", "14:40.920", ["¿Cómo que no?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:40.920", "14:44.600", ["Óigame, el contrato que usted hizo con Rurecismo."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:44.600", "14:45.600", ["El contrato."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:45.600", "14:47.360", ["El contrato que hizo con Rurecismo."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:47.360", "14:49.760", ["Es por seis meses, por rogables."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:49.760", "14:50.920", ["Por rogables."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:50.920", "14:52.840", ["¿Y no va más que todo lo que llevamos ahí?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:52.840", "14:56.720", ["Sí, pero con lo que yo he visto que han hecho ustedes, ya tengo bastante."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "14:56.720", "15:00.200", ["Figúrese, señor juez, que en un palmar que había en la finca lo cortaron todo."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:00.200", "15:03.800", ["Bueno, pero eso fue para sembrar frutales en vez de palmas."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:03.800", "15:06.680", ["Porque las palmas, si se va a ver, caballeros, no producen nada."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:06.680", "15:07.720", ["¿Cómo que no producen nada?"]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:07.720", "15:09.200", ["Usted sabe algo de palmas."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:09.200", "15:10.240", ["Hombre, cómo no, chico."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:10.240", "15:12.720", ["Yo conozco toda la clase de palmas que Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:14.160", "15:14.800", ["Hay muchas."]), Main.Notebook.EntryVTT(:caption, "", "15:14.800", "15:16.040", ["Ya lo creo que sí, chico."]), textconfig = TextConfig(
    group_usr=true,
    group_url=true,
    del_diac=true,
    lc=true,
    group_num=true,
    nlist=[1],
    qlist=[])

# corpus here can be a sample to avoid double parsing
voc = Vocabulary(textconfig, D.caption) 
model = VectorModel(IdfWeighting(), TfWeighting(), voc)
# model = VectorModel(EntropyWeighting(), BinaryLocalWeighting(), voc, D.text, D.klass; smooth=1.0)

model = filter_tokens(model) do t
    t.weight >= 0.05
end

vectors = vectorize_corpus(model, D.caption)

text:
UMAP projections
UMAP projection can take a while, even on multithreading systems. Note that we are creating 2d and 3d projections.

1e2, e3 = let min_dist=0.5f0,
             k=16,
             n_epochs=75,
             neg_sample_rate=3,
             tol=1e-3,
             layout=SpectralLayout(),
             indexsize=2048,
             dist=NormalizedCosineDistance()

    index = ExhaustiveSearch(; db=rand(vectors, indexsize), dist)
    @time U2 = fit(UMAP, index; k, neg_sample_rate, layout, n_epochs, tol, min_dist)
    @time U3 = fit(U2, 3; neg_sample_rate, n_epochs, tol)
    @time e2 = clamp.(predict(U2, vectors), -10f0, 10f0)
    @time e3 = clamp.(predict(U3, vectors), -10f0, 10f0)
    e2, e3
end


1

The UMAP algorithm has a lot of hyperparameters; min_dist controls the distance between projected points, k is the number of neighbors to be used in the underlying \(k\)nn graph, n_epochs the number of epochs used to optimize the projection, neg_sample_rate means for the number of negative examples used in the optimization process, tol the tolerance to converge, layout

title: Searching in podcast collection
text:
Visualizations

function normcolors(V)
    min_, max_ = extrema(V)
    V .= (V .- min_) ./ (max_ - min_)
    V .= clamp.(V, 0, 1)
end

normcolors(@view e3[1, :])
normcolors(@view e3[2, :])
normcolors(@view e3[3, :])

C = [RGB(c[1], c[2], c[3]) for c in eachcol(e3)]

X = @view e2[1, :]
Y = @view e2[2, :]
scatter(X, Y, color=C, fmt=:png, alpha=0.2, size=(600, 600), ma=0.3, ms=2, msw=0, label="")

plot!()





dbscanresult = dbscan(e2, 0.035, min_cluster_size=10);


display(length(dbscanresult.clusters))

plot()
for c in dbscanresult.clusters
    X = @view e2[1, c.core_indices]
    Y = @view e2[2, c.core_indices]
    scatter!(X, Y, c=:auto, fmt=:png, size=(600, 600), ma=0.3, a=0.3, ms=1, msw=0, label="")
    if rand() < 0.1  # just to show some examples 
        display(latexify(D[c.core_indices, :], env=:mdtable, latex=false))
    end
end

plot!()

title: Using with ManifoldLearning
text:
by: Eric S. Téllez
This demonstration is about using SimilaritySearch and ManifoldLearning methods through SimSearchManifoldLearning.
using SimilaritySearch, SimSearchManifoldLearning, ManifoldLearning, Primes, Plots, StatsPlots, StatsBase, LinearAlgebra, Markdown, Random

title: Using with ManifoldLearning
text:
SCurve example

X, L = ManifoldLearning.scurve(segments=5)

scatter(X[1, :], X[2, :], X[3, :], color=L, alpha=0.5)




  
    
  



  
    
  


  
    
  

















































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































































SimilaritySearch support exact and approximate algorithms to solve k nearest neighbors. Also, it supports different metrics. For instance, let see how the selection of the distance function modifies the projection.

Manhattan distance (\(L_1\))

let Y = predict(fit(Isomap, X, nntype=ApproxManhattan))
    scatter(Y[1,:], Y[2,:], color=L, alpha=0.5)
end

title: Using with ManifoldLearning
text:
Visualizing prime gaps
The difference between contiguous prime numbers is called a Prime gap. We use this series of values as a time series example due to its interesting behavior and since it can be computed without downloading more than the necessary packages.
This example shows how to generate the dataset and index it. We will use the ManifoldLearning for generating the 2d visualization.

Generation of the dataset
The time series is represented with windows of size w, we also take log of gaps to reduce variance in gap values. We create a matrix to avoid redefinition of the knn interface for ManifoldLearning.

function create_database_primes_diff(n, w)
    T = log2.(diff(primes(n)))
    M = Matrix{Float32}(undef, w, length(T) - w)
    @info size(M)
    for i in 1:size(M, 2)
        M[:, i] .= view(T, i:(i+w-1))
    end

    M
end


x, y = let
    P = create_database_primes_diff(3 * 10^4, 5)
    # or LLE
    primesgap = fit(Isomap, P; k=16, maxoutdim=2, nntype=ApproxEuclidean)
    
    p = predict(primesgap)
    p[1, :], p[2, :]
end

A 2D histogram

histogram2d(x, y; nbins=100)

title: Visualizing MNIST database
text:
by: Eric S. Téllez
This demonstration shows in a 2D example the functionality of SearchGraph.
using SimilaritySearch, SimSearchManifoldLearning, Plots, StatsBase, LinearAlgebra, Markdown, Random
n = 100_000

M = randn(Float16, 2, n)
db = MatrixDatabase(M)
dist = SqL2_asf32()
size(M)
Now we can create the index
1G = SearchGraph(; dist, db)
ctx = SearchGraphContext(hyperparameters_callback=OptimizeParameters(MinRecall(0.99)))
2index!(G, ctx)
3optimize_index!(G, ctx, MinRecall(0.9))


1

Defines the index and the search context (caches and hyperparameters); particularly, we use a very high quality build MinRecall(0.99); high quality constructions yield to faster queries due to the underlying graph structure.

2

Actual indexing procedure using the given search context.

3

Optimizing the index to trade quality and speed.

title: Visualizing MNIST database
text:
The set of queries
We define a small set of queries being close to the border of the dataset and also in the most dense regions of the dataset.

Q = [Float32[-2, -2], Float32[2, -2], Float32[-2, 0], Float32[-0, 2], Float32[0, 0],   Float32[-3, 3],  Float32[4, 4], Float32[1, 0.5]]
I, D = searchbatch(G, ctx, VectorDatabase(Q), 30)

Please note how queries in low and high dense regions are located.

scatter(view(M, 1, :), view(M, 2, :), fmt=:png, c=:cyan, ma=0.3, a=0.3, ms=1, msw=0)

scatter!(getindex.(Q, 1), getindex.(Q, 2), c=:red, ma=0.7, a=0.7, ms=6, msw=0)

for c in eachcol(I)
    X = M[:, c]
    scatter!(view(X, 1, :), view(X, 2, :), c=:blue, ma=0.5, a=0.5, ms=2, msw=0)
    #scatter!( c=:auto, ms=2)
end

plot!(legend=nothing)

Since points are distributed in several regions with disparate density, their radii are also quite diverse. The next figure illustrates this effect.

title: Visualizing MNIST database
section: Distribution of distances for the set of queries
text:
Distribution of distances for the set of queries

plot(D, m=:auto, yscale=:log10, title="knn distances for elements in Q", fmt=:png)

title: Visualizing Twitter Messages with Emojis
text:
by: Eric S. Téllez
This example creates a visualization of Glove word embeddings using Embeddings.jl package to fetch them.
Note: This example needs a lot of computing power; therefore you may want to set the environment variable JULIA_NUM_THREADS=auto before running julia.
using SimilaritySearch, SimSearchManifoldLearning, TextSearch, CodecZlib, JSON, DataFrames, Plots, StatsBase, LinearAlgebra, Markdown, Embeddings, Random
using Downloads: download
emb, vocab = let emb = load_embeddings(GloVe{:en}, 2)  # you can change with any of the available embeddings in `Embeddings`
    for c in eachcol(emb.embeddings)
1        normalize!(c)
    end

2    Float16.(emb.embeddings), emb.vocab
end

3dist = NormalizedCosine_asf32()
4vocab2id = Dict(w => i for (i, w) in enumerate(vocab))


1

Normalizes all vectors to have a unitary norm; this allow us to use the dot product as similarity (see point 3)

2

The speed can be improved through memory’s bandwidth using less memory per vector; using Float16 as memory representation is a good idea even if your computer doesn’t support 16-bit floating point arithmetic natively.

3

Since we have unitary norm vectors we can simplify the cosine distance (i.e., \(1 - dot(\cdot, \cdot)\)); note that we are using Float16 and the suffix _asf32 will select a distance function that converts numbers to Float32 just before performing arithmetic operations.

4

Inverse map from words to identifiers in vocab.
Now we can create the index
1index = SearchGraph(; dist, db=MatrixDatabase(emb))
ctx = SearchGraphContext(hyperparameters_callback=OptimizeParameters(MinRecall(0.99)))
2index!(index, ctx)
3optimize_index!(index, ctx, MinRecall(0.9))


1

Defines the index and the search context (caches and hyperparameters); particularly, we use a very high quality build MinRecall(0.99); high quality constructions yield to faster queries due to the underlying graph structure.

2

Actual indexing procedure using the given search context.

3

Optimizing the index to trade quality and speed.

title: Visualizing Twitter Messages with Emojis
text:
UMAP Visualization

function normcolors(V)
    min_, max_ = extrema(V)
    V .= (V .- min_) ./ (max_ - min_)
    V .= clamp.(V, 0, 1)
end

normcolors(@view e3[1, :])
normcolors(@view e3[2, :])
normcolors(@view e3[3, :])

let C = [RGB(c[1], c[2], c[3]) for c in eachcol(e3)],
    X = view(e2, 1, :),
    Y = view(e2, 2, :)
    scatter(X, Y, color=C, fmt=:png, alpha=0.2, size=(600, 600), ma=0.3, ms=2, msw=0, label="", yticks=nothing, xticks=nothing, xaxis=false, yaxis=false)
end

plot!()





e2, e3 = let min_dist=0.5f0,
             k=12,
             n_epochs=75,
             neg_sample_rate=3,
             tol=1e-3,
             layout=RandomLayout()

    @time "Compute 2D UMAP model" U2 = fit(UMAP, index; k, neg_sample_rate, layout, n_epochs, tol, min_dist)
    @time "Compute 3D UMAP model" U3 = fit(U2, 3; neg_sample_rate, n_epochs, tol)
    @time "predicting 2D embeddings" e2 = clamp.(predict(U2), -10f0, 10f0)
    @time "predicting 3D embeddings" e3 = clamp.(predict(U3), -10f0, 10f0)
    e2, e3
end

title: Visualizing Twitter Messages with Emojis
text:
Final notes
This example shows how to index and search dense vector databases, in particular GloVe word embeddings using the cosine distance. Low dimensional projections are made with SimSearchManifoldLearning, note that SimilaritySearch is also used for computing the all \(k\) nearest neighbors needed by the UMAP model. Note that this notebook should be ran with several threads to reduce time costs.

title: Datasets for Nearest Neighbor Search
text:
MNIST. Very used in vision tasks, pretty old and not very challenging. However it is very easy to use. From MNIST site, it corresponds to 60k 28x28 handwritten numbers. We use the MLDatasets.jl package to simplify downloading and loading it.
Wiktionary. Took from Wiktionary site, we select English terms from the english wiktionary.
WIT-300K. From Clip and WIT, we downloaded the first 300K annotated images for the Spanish Wikipedia and take the Clip embeddings of them. Available from the demo subfolder.
Glove. Very used as dataset in papers but not yet vigent with respect to state of the art methods in different Natural Language Processing tasks. From Glove site, it corresponds to the 100d, 6B tokens. We use the Embeddings.jl package to simplify downloading and loading it.



The versions used in the demonstrations are not splitted in train and test, but those used in the paper are splitted. If you want to reproduce the same results, please use the datasets by ann-benchmarks and its repo.
For WIT and Twitter-2M, please use the following HDF5 files, they follow a similar structure than those found in the ann-benchmarks.

WIT-300K
Twitter-2M. These word embeddings corresponds to that model labeled as ALL-2M in the Regional Spanish Models site, yet partitioned for using as similarity search benchmark.

title: Visualizing Twitter Messages with Emojis
text:
This example creates a vector space model for classify emojis in Twitter messages, then process and create vectors from messages and project them using a UMAP model. The projection uses the SimilaritySearch allknn operation.
using SimilaritySearch, SimSearchManifoldLearning, TextSearch, CodecZlib, JSON, DataFrames, Plots, StatsBase
using Downloads: download
downloading the dataset, parsing and vectorizing functions
mkpath("tmp")
dbfile = "tmp/emo50k.json.gz"
baseurl = "https://github.com/sadit/TextClassificationTutorial/raw/refs/heads/main/data/emo50k.json.gz"
!isfile(dbfile) && download(baseurl, dbfile)

false
Now, we load the dataset
D = DataFrame(open(GzipDecompressorStream, dbfile) do f
    JSON.parse.(eachline(f))
end)

collect(countmap(D.klass))

64-element Vector{Pair{String, Int64}}:
 "✨" => 801
 "🤤" => 771
 "😁" => 794
 "😡" => 776
 "😏" => 757
 "🤣" => 780
 "👌" => 779
 "😭" => 785
 "🤔" => 732
 "😈" => 774
      ⋮
 "🙄" => 748
 "💙" => 770
 "🙊" => 786
 "😘" => 815
 "🙈" => 772
 "💕" => 747
 "😑" => 812
 "😔" => 782
 "😳" => 839
D = filter(D) do r
    r.klass in ("😭", "🤣", "😍", "😤")
end

collect(countmap(D.klass))
#H = sort!(collect(countmap(D.klass)), by=first)
#bar(first.(H), last.(H))

4-element Vector{Pair{String, Int64}}:
 "🤣" => 780
 "😤" => 808
 "😭" => 785
 "😍" => 816
Functions create to encode texto into bag-of-word vectors
textconfig = TextConfig(
    group_usr=true,
    group_url=true,
    del_diac=true,
    lc=true,
    group_num=true,
    nlist=[1],
    qlist=[3])

# corpus here can be a sample to avoid double parsing
voc = Vocabulary(textconfig, D.text) 
# model = VectorModel(IdfWeighting(), TfWeighting(), voc)
model = VectorModel(EntropyWeighting(), BinaryLocalWeighting(), voc, D.text, D.klass; smooth=1.0)
#model = VectorModel(IdfWeighting(), TfWeighting(), voc)
model = filter_tokens(model) do t
    t.weight >= 0.075
end
vectors = vectorize_corpus(model, D.text)

title: Visualizing Twitter Messages with Emojis
text:
UMAP projections
UMAP projection can take a while, even on multithreading systems. Note that we are creating 2d and 3d projections.

1e2, e3 = let min_dist=0.5f0,
             k=16,
             n_epochs=75,
             neg_sample_rate=3,
             tol=1e-3,
             layout=SpectralLayout(),
             indexsize=768,
             dist=NormalizedCosineDistance()

    index = ExhaustiveSearch(; db=rand(vectors, indexsize), dist)
    @time U2 = fit(UMAP, index; k, neg_sample_rate, layout, n_epochs, tol, min_dist)
    @time U3 = fit(U2, 3; neg_sample_rate, n_epochs, tol)
    @time e2 = clamp.(predict(U2, vectors), -10f0, 10f0)
    @time e3 = clamp.(predict(U3, vectors), -10f0, 10f0)
    e2, e3
end


1

The UMAP algorithm has a lot of hyperparameters; min_dist controls the distance between projected points, k is the number of neighbors to be used in the underlying \(k\)nn graph, n_epochs the number of epochs used to optimize the projection, neg_sample_rate means for the number of negative examples used in the optimization process, tol the tolerance to converge, layout

title: Visualizing MNIST database
text:
by: Eric S. Téllez
This example creates a visualization of the MNIST images (hand written digits) using MLDatasets.jl to retrieve it.
Note: This example needs a lot of computing power; therefore you may want to set the environment variable JULIA_NUM_THREADS=auto before running julia.
using SimilaritySearch, SimSearchManifoldLearning, Plots, StatsBase, LinearAlgebra, Markdown, MLDatasets, Random
db, y, dist = let data = MNIST(split=:train)
    T, y = data.features, data.targets
    n = size(T, 3)
    MatrixDatabase(Float32.(reshape(T, (28*28, n)))), y, SqL2_asf32()
end
Now we can create the index
1index = SearchGraph(; dist, db)
ctx = SearchGraphContext(hyperparameters_callback=OptimizeParameters(MinRecall(0.99)))
2index!(index, ctx)
3optimize_index!(index, ctx, MinRecall(0.95))


1

Defines the index and the search context (caches and hyperparameters); particularly, we use a very high quality build MinRecall(0.99); high quality constructions yield to faster queries due to the underlying graph structure.

2

Actual indexing procedure using the given search context.

3

Optimizing the index to trade quality and speed.

title: Prime numbers
text:
by: Eric S. Téllez
This demonstration is about prime numbers and its similarity based on its factors. This is a well-known demonstration of SimSearchManifoldLearning.jl. This notebook does not requires to download any dataset.
Note: This example needs a lot of computing power; therefore you may want to set the environment variable JULIA_NUM_THREADS=auto before running julia.
using SimilaritySearch, SimSearchManifoldLearning, Primes, Plots, StatsBase, LinearAlgebra, Markdown, Random
Now, we can define our dataset. The set of factors are found using the Primes package. Note that we use VectorDatabase to represent the dataset.
n = 100_000
F = Vector{Vector{Int32}}(undef, n+1)

function encode_factors(num)
    sort!(Int32[convert(Int32, f) for f in factor(Set, num)])
end

F[1] = Int32[1]

for i in 2:n+1
    s = encode_factors(i)
    F[i] = s
end

db = VectorDatabase(F)
#dist = JaccardDistance()  # Other distances from SimilaritySearch
#dist = IntersectionDissimilarity()
#dist = CosineDistanceSet()
dist = DiceDistance()
We use Int32 ordered arrays to store prime factors to represent each integer. In the following cell define the cosine distance equivalent for this representation. While other representations may perform faster, this is quite straighforward and demonstrates the use of user’s defined distance functions.

title: Prime numbers
text:
Index construction
Note that the primes factors are pretty large for some large \(n\) and this imply challengues for metric indexes (since it is related with the intrinsic dimension of the dataset). We used a kernel that starts 64 threads, it solves \(100000\) in a few seconds but it can take pretty large time using single threads and larger \(n\) values. The construction of the index is used by the visualization algorithm (UMAP) to construct an all-knn graph, which can be a quite costly procedure.

G = SearchGraph(; db, dist)
1ctx = SearchGraphContext(hyperparameters_callback=OptimizeParameters(MinRecall(0.95)))
2index!(G, ctx)
3optimize_index!(G, ctx, MinRecall(0.9))


1

Defines the index and the search context (caches and hyperparameters); particularly, we use a very high quality build MinRecall(0.95); high quality constructions yield to faster queries due to the underlying graph structure.

2

Actual indexing procedure using the given search context.

3

Optimizing the index to trade quality and speed.

title: Prime numbers
text:
Visualizing with UMAP projection
We select to initialize the embedding randomly, this could yield to low quality embeddings, but it is much faster than other techniques like spectral layout. Note that we pass the Search graph G. We also use a second call to compute a 3D embedding for computing a kind of colour embedding, here we pass U2 to avoid recomputing several of the involved structures.

function normcolors(V)
    min_, max_ = extrema(V)
    V .= (V .- min_) ./ (max_ - min_)
    V .= clamp.(V, 0, 1)
end

normcolors(@view e3[1, :])
normcolors(@view e3[2, :])
normcolors(@view e3[3, :])

let C = [RGB(c[1], c[2], c[3]) for c in eachcol(e3)],
    X = view(e2, 1, :),
    Y = view(e2, 2, :)
    scatter(X, Y, color=C, fmt=:png, alpha=0.2, size=(600, 600), ma=0.3, ms=2, msw=0, label="", yticks=nothing, xticks=nothing, xaxis=false, yaxis=false)
end

plot!()





e2, e3 = let min_dist=0.5f0,
             k=20,
             n_epochs=75,
             neg_sample_rate=3,
             tol=1e-3,
             layout=SpectralLayout()

    @time "Compute 2D UMAP model" U2 = fit(UMAP, G; k, neg_sample_rate, layout, n_epochs, tol, min_dist)
    @time "Compute 3D UMAP model" U3 = fit(U2, 3; neg_sample_rate, n_epochs, tol)
    @time "predicting 2D embeddings" e2 = clamp.(predict(U2), -10f0, 10f0)
    @time "predicting 3D embeddings" e3 = clamp.(predict(U3), -10f0, 10f0)
    e2, e3
end

title: Tutorials and Examples for the SimilaritySearch.jl package
text: Here you will find several examples for the SimilaritySearch.jl package.

title: Tutorials and Examples for the SimilaritySearch.jl package
text:
Installation
You need a Julia installation https://julialang.org/downloads/, in particular, we recommend to use Julia \(v1.10\) since \(v1.11\) has several performance regressions with respect to SimilaritySearch.
We present our examples just to copy and paste on the REPL but also provide some in Jupyter and Pluto notebooks; you must install IJulia and Pluto packages, just run the following commands in the REPL
using Pkg; Pkg.add(["IJulia", "Pluto"])
Please check their documentation:

IJulia.
Jupyter.
Pluto

This website was made with Quarto with the Julia engine.

title: Tutorials and Examples for the SimilaritySearch.jl package
text:
Notes about multithreading
Nearest neighbor search can be computationally expensive, therefore SimilaritySearch has multithreading support. You should want to run jupyter or julia using all available threads, that is
JULIA_NUM_THREADS=auto jupyter-lab .
or
JULIA_NUM_THREADS=auto julia
Perhaps all your threads may become your computer useless for a while, so you can replace auto by some other more conservative number that allow you to work on the same computer.

title: Tutorials and Examples for the SimilaritySearch.jl package
text:
News

march 20th, 2025: the site is behind the SimilaritySearch API; I will be working on updating examples and moving the site to Quarto.
june 5th, 2023: adds news section, some installation requirements, Jupyter notebookes were updated to work with the v0.10 and with the current julia release v1.9. I also moved most plots to Makie.

title: Tutorials and Examples for the SimilaritySearch.jl package
text:
Problem statement
Given a finite dataset, \(S \subseteq U\) where \(n = |S|\), and a metric distance function \(d\) working with any pair of elements in \(U\), the similarity search problem consists on retrieving similar items to a given query \(q\), for example, the \(k\) most similar items to \(q\) in \(S\) (\(k\) nearest neighbors).
At first glance, the problem is simple since it can be solved using an exhaustive evaluation of all possible results \(d(u_1, q), \cdots, d(u_n, q)\) (that is, for all \(u_i \in S\)) and select those \(k\) items \(\{u_i\}\) having the least distance to \(q\). This solution is impractical when \(n\) is large or when the number of expected queries is high. In these cases, it is necessary to create a data structure that preprocess the dataset and reduce the cost of solving queries, it is often called a metric index. When the dataset is pretty large or the metric space is quite complex, sometimes we can loose the ability of retrieving the exact solution to gain speed, clearly, the approximation quality becomes a major concern and these approximate methods require a lot of knowledge to trade speed retrieval process also kept high the solution’s quality. Additionally, the amount of memory used by the index and the construction time are also concerns whenever \(n\) is big.
The SearchGraph index in the SimilaritySearch.jl package is a competitive alternative for solving search queries that automatically tune search speed and quality and also remains very competitive in memory and construction costs. Here we show some demostrations of how using SimilaritySearch.jl in several synthetic and real problems.

title: Automatic Hyperparameter Optimization
text:
by: Eric S. Téllez
This example optimizes different kinds of optimizations that allow different tradeoffs

using SimilaritySearch, Markdown

1dim = 16
2db = MatrixDatabase(rand(Float32, dim, 10^5))
3queries = MatrixDatabase(rand(Float32, dim, 10^3))
4dist = SqL2Distance()
5k = 12


1

The dimension to use in the synthetic data

2

The synthetic database

3

The synthetic queries

4

The distance function; we will use the squared L2, which preserves the order of L2 but is faster to compute.

5

The number of neighbors to retrieve

text:
by: Eric S. Téllez
This example optimizes different kinds of optimizations that allow different tradeoffs

using SimilaritySearch, Markdown

1dim = 16
2db = MatrixDatabase(rand(Float32, dim, 10^5))
3queries = MatrixDatabase(rand(Float32, dim, 10^3))
4dist = SqL2Distance()
5k = 12


1

The dimension to use in the synthetic data

2

The synthetic database

3

The synthetic queries

4

The distance function; we will use the squared L2, which preserves the order of L2 but is faster to compute.

5

The number of neighbors to retrieve

title: Automatic Hyperparameter Optimization
text:
Computing ground truth
We will generate a ground truth with an exhaustive method.

goldI, goldD = searchbatch(ExhaustiveSearch(; db, dist), GenericContext(), queries, k)

title: Automatic Hyperparameter Optimization
text:
Different hyperparameter optimization strategies
The way of specifying the hyperparameter optimization strategy and objective is with a SearchGraphContext object, as follows:

G1 = SearchGraph(; dist, db)
C1 = SearchGraphContext(hyperparameters_callback=OptimizeParameters(MinRecall(0.99)))
buildtime1 = @elapsed index!(G1, C1)

The previous construction optimizes the construction to have a very high recall, which can be very costly but also produces a high quality index.

G2 = SearchGraph(; dist, db)
C2 = SearchGraphContext(hyperparameters_callback=OptimizeParameters(MinRecall(0.9)))
buildtime2 = @elapsed index!(G2, C2)

search, searchbatch, index!, append_items!, and push_item! accept context arguments.

title: Automatic Hyperparameter Optimization
text:
Performances
searching times

time1 = @elapsed I1, D1 = searchbatch(G1, C1, queries, k)
time2 = @elapsed I2, D2 = searchbatch(G2, C2, queries, k)
recall1 = macrorecall(goldI, I1)
recall2 = macrorecall(goldI, I2)

the recall is an score value between 0 to 1 where values close to 1 indicate better qualities.


build time:

buildtime1: 5.648114106

buildtime2: 0.523501032


search time:

time1: 0.002314346

time2: 0.001370323


recall values:

recall1: 0.96783333333333

recall2: 0.8649999999999989





here we can see smaller recalls than expected, and this is an effect of the difference between indexed elements (that are those objects used to perform the hyperparameter optimization). In any case, we 1can appreciate the differences among them, showing that high quality constructions may produce faster indexes; this is a consequence of the quality of the underlying structure. Contrary to this example, in higher dimensions or large datasets, we will obtain much higher construction times for high quality constructions.

title: Automatic Hyperparameter Optimization
section: Optimizing an already created SearchGraph for achieving a desired quality
text:
Optimizing an already created SearchGraph for achieving a desired quality
The hyperparameter optimization is performed in exponential stages while the SearchGraph is created; and therefore, the current hyperparameters could need an update. To optimize an already created SearchGraph we use optimize instead of index
Context objects are special for construction since they encapsulate several hyperparameters; for searching it contains also caches but it can be shared among indexes; however, if the indexes have different sizes or you expect very different queries, it is better to maintain different context.

optimize_index!(G1, C1, MinRecall(0.9))
optimize_index!(G2, C1, MinRecall(0.9))

after optimizing the index its quality and speed are changed

time1 = @elapsed I1, D1 = searchbatch(G1, C1, queries, k)
time2 = @elapsed I2, D2 = searchbatch(G2, C1, queries, k)

recall1 = macrorecall(goldI, I1)
recall2 = macrorecall(goldI, I2)

These results on the following performances:


build time:

buildtime1: 5.648114106

buildtime2: 0.523501032


search time:

time1: 0.001014245

time2: 0.000905641


recall values:

recall1: 0.6443333333333329

recall2: 0.7148333333333333





Please note that faster searches are expected for indexes created for higher qualities; but the construction must be paid. Note that recall values are lower than expected, as we explained, due to differences in the distributions (more precisely between points already seen and not seen points).

title: Automatic Hyperparameter Optimization
section: Giving more realistic queries for optimization
text:
Giving more realistic queries for optimization
The default optimization parameters use objects already indexed to tune the hyperparameters, which is too optimistic in real applications, since already indexed objects are particularly easy for this use. We can get a better optimization using external data:

optqueries = MatrixDatabase(rand(Float32, dim, 64))

optimize_index!(G1, C1, MinRecall(0.9); queries=optqueries)
optimize_index!(G2, C1, MinRecall(0.9); queries=optqueries)

after optimizing the index its quality and speed are changed

time1 = @elapsed I1, D1 = searchbatch(G1, C1, queries, k)
time2 = @elapsed I2, D2 = searchbatch(G2, C1, queries, k)

recall1 = macrorecall(goldI, I1)
recall2 = macrorecall(goldI, I2)

These results on the following performances:


build time:

buildtime1: 5.648114106

buildtime2: 0.523501032


search time:

time1: 0.013517147

time2: 0.010678581


recall values:

recall1: 0.9045833333333309

recall2: 0.9097499999999987





These scores are much closer to those we are looking for.
Be careful on doing optimize_index!(..., queries=queries) since this can yield to overfitting on your query set.

title: Incremental construction with SearchGraph
text:
by: Eric S. Téllez
using SimilaritySearch
For incremental construction we need a database backend that supports incremental insertions. Currently, there are two backends for this: DynamicMatrixDatabase and VectorDatabase:
dim = 8
db = DynamicMatrixDatabase(Float32, dim) # or VectorDatabase(Vector{Float32})
dist = L1Distance()
it can use any distance function described in SimilaritySearch and Distances.jl, and in fact any SemiMetric as described in the later package. The index construction is made as follows:
G = SearchGraph(; dist, db)
ctx = SearchGraphContext()
instead of index! we can use push_item! and append_items! functions
for _ in 1:10^4
    push_item!(G, ctx, rand(Float32, dim))  # push_item! inserts one item at a time
end
we can also use append_items! if we have a batch of items
append_items!(G, ctx, MatrixDatabase(rand(Float32, dim, 10^4))) # append_items! inserts many items at once
Note that we used a MatrixDatabase to wrap the matrix to be inserted since it will be copied into the index. Now we have a populated index.
@assert length(G) == 20_000
this will display a lot of information in the console, since as construction advances the hyperparameters of the index are adjusted.
Once the index is created, the index can solve nearest neighbor queries
1Q = MatrixDatabase(rand(dim, 30))
2k = 5
3I, D = searchbatch(G, ctx, Q, k)
display((typeof(I), typeof(D)))
display((size(I), size(D)))


1

Creates the query

2

The number of nearest neighbors to retrieve

3

Solve queries, returns neighbor identifiers and distances.




(Matrix{Int32}, Matrix{Float32})


((5, 30), (5, 30))

title: Solving single queries
text:
by: Eric S. Téllez
using SimilaritySearch
This example shows how to perform single queries instead of solving a batch of them. This is particularly useful for some applications, and we also show how they are solved, which could be used to avoid some memory allocations.
dim = 8
db = MatrixDatabase(randn(Float32, dim, 10^4))
queries = db = MatrixDatabase(randn(Float32, dim, 100))
dist = SqL2Distance()
G = SearchGraph(; dist, db)
ctx = SearchGraphContext()
index!(G, ctx)
Suppose you want to compute some \(k\) nearest neighbors, for this we use the structure KnnResult which is a priority queue of maximum size \(k\).
for _ in 1:10
    res = KnnResult(3)

    @time search(G, ctx, randn(Float32, dim), res)
    @show minimum(res), maximum(res), argmin(res), argmax(res)
    @show collect(IdView(res))
    @show collect(DistView(res))
end

title: Solving single queries
text:
KnnResult
This structure is the container for the result and it is also used to specify the number of elements to retrieve. As mentioned before, it is a priority queue


res = KnnResult(4)
push_item!(res, 1, 10)
push_item!(res, 2, 9)
push_item!(res, 3, 8)
push_item!(res, 4, 7)
push_item!(res, 6, 5)
@show res

# it also supports removals
@show :popfirst! => popfirst!(res)
push_item!(res, 7, 0.1)
@show :push_item! => res
@show :pop! => pop!(res)
res
# It can be iterated

@show collect(res)

res = SimilaritySearch.KnnResult(SimilaritySearch.AdjacencyLists.IdWeight[SimilaritySearch.AdjacencyLists.IdWeight(0x00000006, 5.0f0), SimilaritySearch.AdjacencyLists.IdWeight(0x00000004, 7.0f0), SimilaritySearch.AdjacencyLists.IdWeight(0x00000003, 8.0f0), SimilaritySearch.AdjacencyLists.IdWeight(0x00000002, 9.0f0)], 4)
:popfirst! => popfirst!(res) = :popfirst! => SimilaritySearch.AdjacencyLists.IdWeight(0x00000006, 5.0f0)
:push_item! => res = :push_item! => SimilaritySearch.KnnResult(SimilaritySearch.AdjacencyLists.IdWeight[SimilaritySearch.AdjacencyLists.IdWeight(0x00000007, 0.1f0), SimilaritySearch.AdjacencyLists.IdWeight(0x00000004, 7.0f0), SimilaritySearch.AdjacencyLists.IdWeight(0x00000003, 8.0f0), SimilaritySearch.AdjacencyLists.IdWeight(0x00000002, 9.0f0)], 4)
